text: I think that most people assume that their boss has to manage them and they feel a little bit resentful that, why should I manage my boss? They're getting paid more. They are my manager. They have more responsibility. And you can continue to think that way and your career might be fine, but if you embrace that if you manage your boss, they're going to appreciate you much more, you're going to get more opportunities, you're going to have more trust with them, there's all these great things that happen when you decide to manage up.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks Wes why managing up is important and why people aren't doing it well. Wes explains that many people feel resistant to managing their boss because they think it's their manager's job to manage them, not the other way around. She argues that this mindset limits career growth and that those who embrace managing up will see significant benefits in their professional relationships and opportunities.
text_ko: 대부분 사람들은 자신의 상사가 자신을 관리해야 한다고 생각해요. 그래서 '왜 내가 상사를 관리해야 하지?'라며 약간 불만을 느껴요. 상사는 월급도 더 받고, 내 상사고, 책임도 더 많으니까요. 그렇게 계속 생각해도 커리어가 괜찮게 갈 수도 있어요. 그런데 상사를 관리(manage up)하는 태도를 받아들이면 상사가 훨씬 더 고마워하고, 기회도 더 많이 생기고, 신뢰도 더 쌓여요. 상사를 능동적으로 관리하기로 마음먹으면 좋은 일들이 정말 많이 일어나요.
text_zh: 我觉得大部分人都认为应该是老板来管理他们，然后就有点不服气，凭什么要我去管理我老板啊？他们工资比我高，他们是我的上司，责任也比我大。你可以一直这么想，职业发展可能也还行，但是如果你能接受这个观点——主动管理你的老板，他们会更欣赏你，你会得到更多机会，和他们的信任关系也会更好。当你决定向上管理(manage up)的时候，会有很多好处。
text_es: Creo que la mayoría de la gente asume que su jefe tiene que gestionarlos a ellos y se sienten un poco resentidos pensando "¿por qué debería yo gestionar a mi jefe? A él le pagan más. Es mi manager. Tiene más responsabilidad." Y puedes seguir pensando así y tu carrera tal vez esté bien, pero si abrazas la idea de que si gestionas a tu jefe, te va a valorar mucho más, vas a conseguir más oportunidades, vas a tener más confianza con él, hay un montón de cosas buenas que pasan cuando decides hacer "managing up".

text: The idea behind what I call the state change method is that you should punctuate your monologues with state changes. So state changes are anything that shakes your audience awake and adds some variety. So it might be asking people to put something in the chat box. It might be switching from gallery view where you see everyone in that Brady Bunch grid and switch over to screen share, to share something and then switch back.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks Wes about her concept of creating state change in presentations and meetings. Wes explains that most Zoom meetings involve one person talking while everyone else listens silently, which is draining for participants. The state change method involves breaking up monologues with interactive elements to keep the audience engaged and prevent them from zoning out during virtual presentations.
text_ko: 제가 '상태 변화 방법(state change method)'이라고 부르는 거의 핵심은, 혼자서 계속 말할 때 중간중간에 상태 변화를 넣으라는 거예요. 상태 변화(state change)란 청중의 집중을 깨우고 분위기에 변화를 주는 모든 행동을 말해요. 예를 들어 채팅창에 답을 입력해 달라고 요청하는 거나, 브래디 번치(Brady Bunch)처럼 모두가 보이는 갤러리 보기(gallery view)에서 화면 공유(screen share)로 전환해 뭔가를 보여준 뒤 다시 돌아오는 식일 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我说的这个状态切换法(state change method)，核心思想就是你在讲话的时候要不断地变换节奏。状态切换就是任何能让听众打起精神、增加点变化的东西。比如说让大家在聊天框里输入点什么，或者从画廊视图(gallery view)——就是那种能看到所有人的九宫格界面——切换到屏幕共享，展示点内容，然后再切回来。
text_es: La idea detrás de lo que yo llamo el método de cambio de estado es que tienes que interrumpir tus monólogos con cambios de estado. Los cambios de estado son cualquier cosa que despierte a tu audiencia y añada variedad. Puede ser pedirles que escriban algo en el chat. Puede ser cambiar de la vista de galería donde ves a todos en esa cuadrícula estilo Brady Bunch y pasar a compartir pantalla para mostrar algo, y luego regresar.

text: So the idea behind what I call eyes lighting up is that when you're talking to someone and you're explaining something, you're teaching them, you're sharing your startup idea or whatever the normal response is people will want to be polite. So they'll nod and they'll say, 'Oh, okay, that's interesting.' But there's usually a moment in the conversation where their eyes light up because they are genuinely actually interested in what you are saying at that moment.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks about Wes's concept called 'eyes lighting up' in relation to state changes in meetings. Wes explains that when presenting or explaining ideas to people, most listeners will be polite and give generic positive responses. However, there are specific moments when someone becomes genuinely engaged - when their eyes literally light up with interest. This physical reaction provides valuable data about what content truly resonates with your audience.
text_ko: 제가 '눈이 반짝이는 순간(eyes lighting up)'이라고 부르는 건, 누군가랑 얘기하면서 뭔가를 설명하거나 가르치거나 스타트업 아이디어를 공유할 때의 상황을 말해요. 대부분 사람들은 예의상 고개를 끄덕이며 "아, 그래요, 흥미롭네요"라고 하죠. 그런데 대화 중에 한순간 상대방의 눈이 확 반짝이는 때가 있어요. 그때는 진짜로 그 순간에 당신이 하는 말에 관심을 갖고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 我说的"眼睛发光"是这个意思：你跟别人聊天的时候，解释什么东西，教他们，或者分享你的创业想法啥的，一般人都会比较客气，会点点头说"哦，好的，挺有意思的"。但通常聊着聊着会有那么一个瞬间，他们的眼睛突然就亮了，因为那一刻他们是真的对你说的东西感兴趣了。
text_es: Entonces la idea detrás de lo que yo llamo "que se les iluminen los ojos" es que cuando estás hablando con alguien y le estás explicando algo, le estás enseñando, le estás compartiendo tu idea de startup o lo que sea, la respuesta normal es que la gente quiere ser educada. Entonces van a asentir con la cabeza y van a decir "Ah, sí, qué interesante." Pero normalmente hay un momento en la conversación donde se les iluminan los ojos porque realmente están genuinamente interesados en lo que les estás diciendo en ese momento.

text: And ironically, the most senior people are best at managing up. This is why they got promoted in the first place because they were great at managing up to their bosses to understand what was worrying their bosses, what was keeping them up at night so that they could take that off their plate. They're great at keeping their bosses in the loop on what's happening so their bosses, aren't constantly having to ask and pepper them with questions every day.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks why managing up is important and how to do it effectively. Wes addresses the misconception that senior people don't need to manage up anymore once they reach director or VP level. She explains that actually the opposite is true - the most successful senior leaders became successful precisely because they mastered the skill of managing up, understanding their bosses' concerns and proactively communicating to reduce their managers' workload.
vocabulary_highlights: what was keeping them up at night
text_ko: 아이러니하게도, 직급이 높은 분들이 상사와의 관계 관리(managing up)를 제일 잘해요. 사실 그게 바로 그들이 승진한 이유예요. 상사가 무엇을 걱정하는지, 뭐 때문에 밤에 잠을 못 이루는지 파악해서 그 부담을 덜어주거든요. 또 무슨 일이 진행되고 있는지 상사에게 꾸준히 공유해서 상사들이 매일매일 계속 확인하거나 질문을 던질 필요가 없게 만들어요.
text_zh: 很有意思的是，越是高层的人越会向上管理。他们之所以能升到现在的位置，就是因为特别会向上管理——能摸透老板在担心什么，什么事儿让老板睡不着觉，然后主动帮老板分担。他们特别会让老板及时了解情况，这样老板就不用天天追着问这问那了。
text_es: Y paradójicamente, la gente más senior es la que mejor sabe manejar hacia arriba (managing up). Por eso llegaron a donde están en primer lugar: porque eran excelentes manejando la relación con sus jefes, entendiendo qué los tenía preocupados, qué no los dejaba dormir por las noches, para poder quitarles esa carga de encima. Son expertos en mantener a sus jefes al tanto de lo que está pasando, así sus jefes no tienen que estar preguntando constantemente ni bombardeándolos con preguntas todos los días.

text: And so it went from being a conversation about yes or no, are you a helpful person or are you not, are you a team player or are you not into, hey, how do we make sure that the important right things get done? And so it's great for the person who you're saying no to and it's also great for Alex because whenever we had those conversations, I always thought that he was really thoughtful about making sure that the most important projects that we want to work on stayed prioritized.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks Wes for advice on how to say no effectively, mentioning his own struggles with declining requests politely. Wes shares a technique she learned from her colleague Alex, who would reframe 'no' conversations by discussing trade-offs instead of outright rejection. Rather than making it about whether someone is helpful or cooperative, Alex would explain what work would need to be deprioritized if he took on the new request, making it a strategic prioritization discussion.
vocabulary_highlights: are you a team player or are you not
text_ko: 그래서 그 대화는 '너는 도움이 되는 사람이냐, 아니냐', '팀 플레이어냐, 아니냐' 같은 예/아니오 식 논쟁에서 '어떻게 하면 정말로 중요하고 올바른 일들이 제대로 끝나게 할까?'로 바뀌었어요. 그 방식은 거절당하는 사람에게도 좋았고 알렉스에게도 좋았어요. 그런 얘기를 나눌 때마다 저는 알렉스가 우리가 하려는 가장 중요한 프로젝트들이 계속 우선순위에 남도록 정말 신중하게 신경 쓴다고 늘 느꼈거든요.
text_zh: 所以这个对话就从原来的"你到底帮不帮忙"、"你是不是团队合作的人"这种非黑即白的问题，变成了"我们怎么确保重要的事情能做好"。这样对被拒绝的人来说挺好的，对Alex来说也挺好，因为每次我们聊这些的时候，我都觉得他真的很用心在确保最重要的项目能保持优先级。
text_es: Y así pasó de ser una conversación sobre sí o no, ¿eres una persona que ayuda o no?, ¿eres alguien que trabaja en equipo o no?, a algo más como: oye, ¿cómo nos aseguramos de que se hagan las cosas importantes y correctas? Y esto es genial tanto para la persona a la que le estás diciendo que no como para Alex, porque cada vez que teníamos esas conversaciones, siempre me parecía que él realmente se tomaba el tiempo de asegurarse de que los proyectos más importantes en los que queríamos trabajar siguieran siendo prioridad.

text: A lot of times when we write a sentence, there's actually already a point of view or there's a point of view baked in, but you don't want it to be an accidental point of view. I was just talking to my team member about this, she asked me to give her some feedback on something that she wrote and the way that she had written her paragraph was leading for the reader.
speaker: Wes Kao
context: Lenny asks Wes for general writing advice beyond the concepts they've already discussed. Wes emphasizes the importance of studying the technical craft of writing rather than just mimicking social media content. She explains how writers often unconsciously embed a point of view in their sentences, and shares an example of giving feedback to a team member whose writing was inadvertently leading the reader toward a specific conclusion.
text_ko: 글을 쓸 때 문장 안에 이미 관점(point of view)이 녹아 들어가는 경우가 많은데, 그 관점이 의도치 않게 묻어나오는 건 원치 않아요. 방금 팀원이랑 이 얘기를 했는데, 팀원이 자기 글에 대해 피드백을 부탁했어요. 그런데 그가 쓴 단락(paragraph)의 표현 방식이 읽는 사람을 특정 방향으로 이끄는(leading) 식이었어요.
text_zh: 很多时候我们写一句话的时候，其实已经带了某种观点或者说观点已经融入进去了，但你不希望这个观点是无意中带出来的。我刚才跟我团队成员聊这个事，她让我给她写的东西提点意见，结果她那段话的写法明显在引导读者的想法。
text_es: Muchas veces cuando redactamos algo, ya llevamos un punto de vista incorporado, o sea, ya está ahí metido, pero no queremos que sea un punto de vista accidental. Justo estaba hablando de esto con una compañera de mi equipo - me pidió que le diera feedback sobre algo que había escrito y la forma en que había redactado su párrafo estaba dirigiendo al lector hacia una conclusión.
